attributes.title: A Cinematic Universe Could Bode Well For Hasbro
summary: Media conjecture abounds about a possible Hasbro cinematic universe.
A cinematic universe could add depth and consistency to Hasbro’s storytelling.
Increased consumer engagement from the cinematic universe will sell toys and boost Hasbro’s top and bottom lines.

attributes.content:
In the most recent quarterly earnings call, Hasbro (NASDAQ: NASDAQ:HAS) CEO Brian Goldner responded to an analyst's question concerning the next Transformers movie in the following way:

Our plan right now with the studio and film makers, you may have read something about some writers being hired and we have, in fact, brought in Akiva Goldsman to lead a group of writers to really create a strategic plan around Transformers. We think there's any number of stories to be told, that's a brand that's been around for 30 years with amazing canon and mythology. And we would expect the sequel to Transformer movie to happen in 2017.

The media has thrown this quote around conjecturing that Hasbro is planning a "cinematic universe" in which all of its stories, such as television shows, comic books, novels and games, are interconnected in a fictitious universe that provides continuity and consistency in storytelling. While this quote doesn't explicitly say that this will happen, I can understand how the media can read into this and think that Hasbro will follow in the footsteps of Paramount's Star Trek and Walt Disney's (NYSE: DIS) Marvel and Star Wars universes. Hasbro could certainly fortify the storytelling and immersive entertainment components of its Brand Blueprint strategy. Let's take a look at how a cinematic universe could help Hasbro and its investors.

Continuity serves as a draw

In April, Marvel released the highly acclaimed Daredevil series on Netflix (NASDAQ: NFLX). I really liked Daredevil. I found Matt Murdock's good, squaring off with the evil that is Wilson Fisk, quite refreshing in a day and age where Sci-Fi good and evil commonly get blurred. However, as a Walt Disney shareholder, I took note of something else…the characters in the Daredevil series kept referring to a "battle of New York", which turns out to be a reference to the first Avengers movie.

This got the wheels turning in my head, and I began wondering if Daredevil characters will make guest appearances in the next Avengers movie? What about Marvel's Agents of Shield? There are murmurings about how Daredevil is a stepping stone towards The Defenders, a movie that I and millions of others (hopefully) will spend good money to see. And, hopefully, consumers will buy related toys and comic books for themselves and their families.

The same thing could happen with Hasbro's highly popular Transformers' saga. Transformer fans could watch a television show that focuses on one aspect of the universe, such as a G.I Joe live action TV series, and then go to the movies to follow up. Meanwhile, children (and adults) could buy toys to act out the overall storyline from multiple product lines.

Bringing consistency to the Hasbro Universe

Hasbro has always been good at recycling its product lines with every new generation. Unfortunately, with every new reincarnation comes a slightly new, but separate, storyline. I always thought this represented a weakness in Hasbro's strategy and approach. It made it hard for die hard and loyal fans to keep track of all the various reincarnations of storylines. A cinematic universe could bring a sense of continuity to the sagas. There are even suggestions in the media that maybe Hasbro could cross G.I. Joe into the Transformers Universe. It has been done in the comic book world with G.I Joe vs. Transformers.

This will make it harder for Hasbro to recycle product lines over time. However, the recycling could be written into the stories. A fictitious universe is only limited by the human imagination, where characters and their corresponding toys can be created and crossed over into other parts of the universe.

How does this help Hasbro's investors?

Having consistency in storytelling can serve as a strong qualitative catalyst for Hasbro's fundamentals over the long-term. In an age where kids are increasingly being entertained through digital means, it's important for Hasbro to build a loyal brand following in an effort to sell its toys and games. Story related products have proven to perform better within Hasbro's product portfolio. Consumers who consume story content know that if something is going on in the background, they will investigate. What they will find is another aspect of the universe, complete with new characters and toys that will enhance Hasbro's top and bottom lines.

Conclusion

I am a long-term owner of Hasbro's shares. Currently, the company trades at a P/E ratio of 23 vs. 19 for the S&P 500 as a whole, meaning that it's not too exorbitantly overvalued. Interested investors may want to take a small position, while adding shares during downturns. Also, investors can enjoy a 2.6% dividend yield while waiting for Hasbro's new strategies to come to fruition.
